<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9702/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[707, 301, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[755, 325, 904, 340]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 559]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 220, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 672, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{m s}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 168, 88]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 106, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = \rho \Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 536, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 527, 252]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 294]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 306, 536, 323]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 342, 613, 378]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_0\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_0^2 - \chi^2)}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 384, 536, 418]]<|/det|>
\[f_0 = \frac{f_s\nu}{\nu\pm\nu_s}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 428, 537, 462]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 470, 628, 490]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_1 + 1 / C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 501, 596, 521]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_1 + C_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 532, 527, 559]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 571, 530, 590]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 606, 596, 625]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_1 + R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 637, 628, 657]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_1 + 1 / R_2 + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 670, 517, 702]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 717, 558, 735]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 750, 581, 768]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_0\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 780, 536, 813]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[295, 72, 700, 89]]<|/det|>
Answer **all** the questions in the spaces provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 148, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 102, 282, 121]]<|/det|>
Define density.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 163, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 195, 146, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 228]]<|/det|>
A smooth pebble, made from uniform rock, has the shape of an elongated sphere as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 234, 700, 370]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 386, 532, 405]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 418, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
The length of the pebble is \(L\). The cross-section of the pebble, in the plane perpendicular to \(L\), is circular with a maximum radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 464, 917, 497]]<|/det|>
A student investigating the density of the rock makes measurements to determine the values of \(L\), \(r\) and the mass \(M\) of the pebble as follows:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 509, 606, 560]]<|/det|>
\[L = (0.1242\pm 0.0001)\mathrm{m}\\ r = (0.0420\pm 0.0004)\mathrm{m}\\ M = (1.072\pm 0.001)\mathrm{kg}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 573, 181, 591]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 573, 897, 591]]<|/det|>
State the name of a measuring instrument suitable for making this measurement of \(L\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 603, 920, 621]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 634, 180, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 634, 715, 653]]<|/det|>
Determine the percentage uncertainty in the measurement of \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[374, 789, 920, 807]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... % [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 71, 801, 92]]<|/det|>
The density \(\rho\) of the rock from which the pebble in **(b)** is composed is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 97, 541, 127]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \frac{M r^n}{k L}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 792, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is an integer and \(k\) is a constant, with no units, that is equal to 2.094.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 183, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 588, 183]]<|/det|>
Use SI base units to show that \(n\) is equal to \(-2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 304, 920, 323]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 335, 181, 354]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 335, 541, 354]]<|/det|>
Calculate the percentage uncertainty in \(\rho\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 536, 920, 555]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = ................................................... % [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 567, 180, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 566, 920, 600]]<|/det|>
Determine \(\rho\) with its absolute uncertainty. Give your values to the appropriate number of significant figures.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 784, 920, 803]]<|/det|>
\[\rho = \left(\mathrm{............................................}\pm \mathrm{....................}\right)\mathrm{kgm}^{-3} \quad [3]\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 816, 920, 833]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 316, 90]]<|/det|>
Define momentum.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>
Two balls X and Y, of equal diameter but different masses \(0.24 \text{kg}\) and \(0.12 \text{kg}\) respectively, slide towards each other on a frictionless horizontal surface, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 205, 826, 308]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 323, 532, 342]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 355, 920, 389]]<|/det|>
Both balls have initial speed \(2.3 \text{m s}^{-1}\) before they collide with each other. Fig. 2.2 shows the variation with time \(t\) of the force \(F_{\mathrm{y}}\) exerted on ball Y by ball X during the collision.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[207, 400, 784, 686]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 705, 534, 723]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 737, 181, 755]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 737, 662, 755]]<|/det|>
Calculate the kinetic energy of ball X before the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 911, 920, 928]]<|/det|>
<form>kinetic energy = .................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The area enclosed by the lines and the time axis in Fig. 2.2 represents the change in momentum of ball Y during the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 715, 135]]<|/det|>
Determine the magnitude of the change in momentum of ball Y.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[379, 291, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<form>change in momentum = .................................................... $N$ s [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 322, 180, 341]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 322, 737, 341]]<|/det|>
Calculate the magnitude of the velocity of ball Y after the collision.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[500, 478, 920, 497]]<|/det|>
<form>velocity = .................................................... $m s^{-1}$ [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 510, 144, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 510, 910, 543]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 2.3, sketch the variation with time \(t\) of the force \(F_{\mathrm{X}}\) exerted on ball X by ball Y during the collision in (b).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[205, 551, 781, 841]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 860, 534, 878]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2.3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 875, 920, 893]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 907, 920, 924]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 101, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 143, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 91]]<|/det|>
A uniform metal bar, initially unstretched, has sides of length \(w\), \(x\) and \(y\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[368, 97, 626, 247]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 265, 532, 284]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 295, 920, 345]]<|/det|>
The bar is now stretched by a tensile force \(F\) applied to the shaded ends. The changes in the lengths \(x\) and \(y\) are negligible. The bar now has sides of length \(x\), \(y\) and \(z\), as shown in Fig. 3.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[312, 352, 682, 603]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 617, 534, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 647, 730, 666]]<|/det|>
Determine expressions, in terms of some or all of \(F\), \(w\), \(x\), \(y\) and \(z\), for:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 677, 181, 696]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 677, 603, 696]]<|/det|>
the stress \(\sigma\) applied to the bar by the tensile force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 724, 920, 742]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\sigma =\)  .................................. ........................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 755, 181, 774]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 755, 562, 774]]<|/det|>
the strain \(\varepsilon\) in the bar due to the tensile force

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 802, 920, 821]]<|/det|>
<form>\(\varepsilon =\)  ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 833, 180, 851]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 833, 707, 851]]<|/det|>
the Young modulus \(E\) of the metal from which the bar is made.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 926, 920, 944]]<|/det|>
<form>E =  ........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 926, 920, 944]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
A copper wire is stretched by a tensile force that gradually increases from 0 to 280N. The variation with extension of the tensile force is shown in Fig. 3.3.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 114, 845, 435]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[462, 450, 534, 469]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 482, 181, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 481, 789, 500]]<|/det|>
State the maximum extension of the wire for which it obeys Hooke's law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 510, 920, 530]]<|/det|>
<form>extension = .................................................... mm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 543, 181, 562]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 543, 900, 562]]<|/det|>
Use Fig. 3.3 to determine the strain energy in the wire when the tensile force is 120N.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 714, 920, 733]]<|/det|>
<form>strain energy = .................................................... J [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 744, 181, 763]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 744, 920, 778]]<|/det|>
Explain why the work done in stretching the wire to an extension of \(12\mathrm{mm}\) is not equal to the energy recovered when the tensile force is removed.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 881, 920, 900]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 10]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 917, 92]]<|/det|>
By reference to the direction of transfer of energy, state what is meant by a longitudinal wave.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 164, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 214]]<|/det|>
A vehicle travels at constant speed around a wide circular track. It continuously sounds its horn, which emits a single note of frequency \(1.2\mathrm{kHz}\). An observer is a large distance away from the track, as shown in the view from above in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 222, 880, 403]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 418, 591, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 920, 483]]<|/det|>
Fig. 4.2 shows the variation with time of the frequency \(f\) of the sound of the horn that is detected by the observer. The time taken for the vehicle to travel once around the track is \(T\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 492, 836, 812]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 828, 534, 846]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 366, 90]]<|/det|>
State Kirchhoff's first law.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 195, 141, 213]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 195, 920, 230]]<|/det|>
The circuit shown in Fig. 5.1 contains a battery of electromotive force (e.m.f.) \(E\) and negligible internal resistance connected to four resistors \(\mathsf{R}_1\) , \(\mathsf{R}_2\) , \(\mathsf{R}_3\) and \(\mathsf{R}_4\) , each of resistance \(R\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[255, 237, 737, 485]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 503, 532, 521]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 5.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 534, 803, 553]]<|/det|>
The current in \(\mathsf{R}_3\) is \(0.30\mathsf{A}\) and the potential difference (p.d.) across \(\mathsf{R}_4\) is \(2.4\mathsf{V}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 566, 181, 584]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 566, 440, 584]]<|/det|>
Show that \(R\) is equal to \(4.0 \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 705, 920, 723]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 736, 181, 755]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 736, 500, 755]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 858, 920, 876]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
The battery in **(b)** is replaced with another battery of the same e.m.f. \(E\) but with an internal resistance that is not negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 808, 135]]<|/det|>
State and explain the change, if any, in the total power produced by the battery.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 240, 146, 259]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 240, 917, 273]]<|/det|>
The resistors in the circuit of Fig. 5.1 are made from nichrome wire of uniform radius \(240 \mu \text{m}\). The length of this wire needed to make each resistor is \(0.67 \text{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 287, 457, 304]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[487, 476, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<form>resistivity = ............................................... \(\Omega \text{m}\) [3]
